quotes:
[]Author: Ruth Winig;
Rating: 4
When: a week ago
What we loved: This hotel has a magical leg up on all others - the view! Yes, you will pay more for it but WOW. It is special to come home after touring Rome and sit atop a roof gazing at St Peters Basilica and looking over the city. We did this every night and every morning ‚ù§Ô∏è The staff! Amazing, nice, well spoken and support needs and requests in a timely manner (speak many languages!) Cleanliness!(with one exception see below) Breakfast - full breakfast that included Italian favorites (cornetti yum!) and traditional American (bacon and eggs yum!) Drinks! Delicious Coffee - hot and ready! What wasn‚Äôt so great: We chose this hotel during the pandemic for its convenient location to the Vatican and its restaurant and bar. We were disappointed that both evening occasions in the roof top bar our waiter (same both evenings) was not accommodating and somewhat rude. On our last night we asked to sit on top and they said it was closed, and seated us on the lower level, then a half hour later we saw service occurring upstairs - why pay for a supreme view of as a guest you can‚Äôt access it during ‚Äúopen‚Äù hours? We settled for the Lower level, still nice views and then at 10:55 we asked for one more drink - people had bottles of wine on ice still so we figured good to go. We were told by the waiter ‚Äú no the bar is closed‚Äù he then walked upstairs to the roof top area weren‚Äôt allowed to drink at. We continued to wait for our bill only to see the bartender make another full tray of drinks and coffee. What??!?! We were stung a bit but shrugged it off. Just felt wrong.

Author: Lessley Ann;
Rating: 5
When: 10 months ago
We took advantage of fabulous postcorona offer. And for the price we got more than expected. A modern room and breakfast in an outstanding panoramatic rooftop restaurant with huge glass windows. Internet worked well. Nothing to complain about.

Author: Chacha Durazo;
Rating: 2
When: 9 months ago
Our AC doesn't work. The room is incredibly dated and questionably clean. Location is great but I will definitely look elsewhere in the future. They left our bags in the main lobby for several hours unattended even though we were promised they would put them in our room (we checked in early but as the room wasn't ready, we left our bags and returned in the evening several hours later). Carpet everywhere which is gross. Definitely not the 4 star they market themselves as.

Author: Marek Grabowski;
Rating: 1
When: 7 months ago
SCAM, BEWARE - THIEFS OPERATE IN THE HOTEL We were attacked by a thief inside the hotel in the morning while going for breakfast. He walked in freely to 3rd floor, and jumped on us in a narrow corridor, hitting me in the face and pushing down the stairs. Thankfully other guests came with help and he run away. The hotel didn‚Äôt care. The reception was empty once I went down (nobody checks who enters the hotel). Finally the receptionist appeared and said he didn‚Äôt see anything (well, not surprisingly) and that‚Äôs a normal thing. They didn‚Äôt even bother to check if the thief left the hotel or to notify the police. I left my number for a manager who didn‚Äôt bother to call me. I never felt such disregard for guests even in 1-star hotels. Unless this hotel cooperate with thiefs which would explain their approach. CHOOSE THIS HOTEL FOR YOUR OWN RISK.

Author: Tony Popa;
Rating: 5
When: a year ago
The Museo di Roma is a museum in Rome, Italy, part of the network of Roman civic museums. The museum was founded in the Fascist era with the aim of documenting the local history and traditions of the "old Rome" that was rapidly disappearing, but following many donations and acquisitions of works of art is now principally an art museum. The collections initially included 120 water-colours by the nineteenth-century painter Ettore Roesler Franz of Roma sparita, "vanished Rome", later moved to the Museo di Roma in Trastevere.

quotes:
[]Author: Father Kenny Ang;
Rating: 5
When: 7 months ago
This is one of my favorite churches in Rome, since I especially love Caravaggio and his works. Every time I come here, I almost always head directly to the Contarelli chapel just to delight in his three paintings of St. Matthew. My favorite one is the Calling of St. Matthew on the left-side wall of the chapel (which is the darker side of the wall, unfortunately). When I went there yesterday, some ladies already put some euros into the machine so the entire chapel was brightly illuminated. I was a lucky pilgrim and photographer!

Author: Veranika Tsybulskaya;

[]Author: Stefano Bucciarelli;
Rating: 4
When: 6 months ago
I would have liked... I would have paid to watch the spectacle of the carriages, wagons and carts passing through the old narrow streets without pavement of vanished Rome. As their number increased dramatically, many of the fountains the city had equipped itself with, which reduced the carriageway, began to create problems. Moving them for traffic reasons was a widespread practice and via della Scrofa follows exactly the layout of an ancient Roman road and the fountain of the same name has not escaped the rule. But the memory of it remains in a bas-relief left in its original position, along the facade of the building that was the convent of the Augustinians. While not far away, right at the corner with via dei Portoghesi, there is now the small hanging tub with the superimposition of a simple cinnamon, from which a jet of fresh water comes out. It is protected by three small columns connected to each other by two iron bars.

Author: Stefano Manzo;
Rating: 5
When: 2 years ago
The Fontana della Scrofa (located in the street of the same name) is located in the VIII Eustachio district, once it was in the position, where today there is a bas-relief depicting a sow. In the fifteenth century the bas-relief was walled up and at the end of the sixteenth century it was transformed into a fountain with the addition of a small basin. In 1874 with Rome became the capital of Italy, the traffic in the area increased dramatically and therefore was a hindrance, so the bas-relief remained at its original point, while the fountain itself was moved a short distance to the corner of the street with Via dei Pellegrini . The above is indicated in an inscription placed below the bas-relief: IN THIS PLACE IT WAS PLACED FOUNTAIN MOVED TO THE CORNER OF THE VIA DEI PORTOGHESI IN THE YEAR 1874 The fountain then placed at the aforementioned corner is made up of a small nozzle, from which the water that flows onto the cup-shaped basin comes out, from which in turn the water arrives in a collection basin on the ground. Three columns connected by bars that serve as an area of ‚Äã‚Äãprotection are placed as protection.

Author: Alessandro Romanella;
Rating: 4
When: 3 years ago
The "real" fountain of the Scrofa existed in the same street that takes its name, and was built in 1580 at the behest of Pope Gregory XIII. In 1873 it was moved because it caused considerable obstruction to traffic. The bas-relief was left in its original position, and instead the small cup-shaped hanging basin was moved a little further on, just at the corner with Via dei Portoghesi.

[]Author: KH Wong;

Author: Stefano Bucciarelli;
Rating: 4
When: 6 months ago
It characterizes the square Every time I try the history books, I rub my eyes to reread the events of this city. In Piazza Nicosia, suffocated by parked cars, there is the beautiful fountain designed by Giacomo Della Porta. Not just any one, because in Rome there are many works that bear his signature. But this one is not like the others and it was not as we see it today, because it was originally located in Piazza del Popolo, long before Valadier dedicated himself to it heart and soul with his genius. What we see remains: the elevated octagonal basin, the elegant balustrade in cipollino marble and a basin decorated with heraldic emblems. Only three small columns connected by two iron bars protect it from modernity.

Author: Maria Tanasa;
Rating: 5
When: 9 months ago
The fountain in Piazza Nicosia was originally located in Piazza del Popolo, was built in 1572 by Giacomo della Porta for Pope Gregory XIII Boncompagni, whose dragon we note on the basin, to inaugurate the restoration of the Virgin Aqueduct. When Giuseppe Valadier carried out the current restyling of the Piazza del Popolo in 1823, it was demolished to be relocated to Piazza Nicosia in 1950, when renovation work was carried out on the area coordinated by the architect Marcello Piacentini.

Author: Stefano Manzo;
Rating: 3
When: 2 years ago
The Fontana del Trullo was designed by Giacomo Della Porta in 1572. Today it is located in Piazza Nicosia, it was placed here in 1950 (after having been dismantled for several years in the warehouses of the municipality). Very beautiful is the octagonal basin, raised by two steps of the same shape, is the only original part left, the rest are reconstructions. Fortunately it is protected by an area of ‚Äã‚Äãrespect delimited by columns, connected with iron bars. Unfortunately, the vehicles parked around and the small size of the Piazza, do not give the right emphasis to the work.

[]Author: Stefano Manzo;
Rating: 4
When: 7 months ago
The Fountain of the Chancellery, fully functional and with a somewhat unusual shape, is located in the VI district (Parione), leaning against a wall of a building near the Piazza della Cancelleria. History: The Fontanella is one of those created by Publio Morbiducci, winner of a competition promoted by the Governorate of Rome, in 1928, for the replacement of some cast iron fountains, with others of greater decoration. It was made entirely of travertine, a stone that is the symbol of the city of Rome. It was inaugurated on October 28, 1929. Description of the Work: The fountain is placed on a small rectangular porphyry rise, bordered by travertine which also determines an area of ‚Äã‚Äãrespect, has a particular predominantly triangular configuration, which rests on two cylinders placed at the sides, in the lower part and is surmounted by a hemisphere with four wedges In the center there is an oval medallion, surmounted by a cardinal's hat and a cross and two bas-reliefs inside, the upper one representing a griffin symbol of the Parione district, in which there is the fountain and in the lower part a flower-shaped tile , in the center of which there is a curved cinnamon from which the water flows out and pours into a small rectangular basin, with the features of a small Roman sarcophagus, where on the front side on a scroll is the inscription SPQR NOTE on the state of conservation of the work: It is discreet even if it requires the removal of limestone encrustations and in my opinion a larger area of ‚Äã‚Äãrespect should be created, perhaps with columns joined by iron bars, to prevent the parking of cars or scooters less than one meter away. NOTE FOUNTAINS IN ROME The fountains in Rome are one of the characteristic elements of the Eternal City, some say it is the city with the most fountains in the world. They have been an important element since ancient Rome, today in addition to the typical cast iron fountains called "nasoni" (around 2000), there are very beautiful ones located in the most diverse places, such as villas, squares, streets, courtyards and more. Some were made by the greatest artistic geniuses of all time, one name above all Gian Lorenzo Bernini. The importance they have in street furniture is also evidenced by the admiring glances of tourists and by the fact that they also have the social utility of quenching thirst after perhaps a long walk in the sun.

What we loved: This hotel has a magical leg up on all others - the view! Yes, you will pay more for it but WOW. It is special to come home after touring Rome and sit atop a roof gazing at St Peters Basilica and looking over the city. We did this every night and every morning ‚ù§Ô∏è The staff! Amazing, nice, well spoken and support needs and requests in a timely manner (speak many languages!) Cleanliness!(with one exception see below) Breakfast - full breakfast that included Italian favorites (cornetti yum!) and traditional American (bacon and eggs yum!) Drinks! Delicious Coffee - hot and ready! What wasn‚Äôt so great: We chose this hotel during the pandemic for its convenient location to the Vatican and its restaurant and bar. We were disappointed that both evening occasions in the roof top bar our waiter (same both evenings) was not accommodating and somewhat rude. On our last night we asked to sit on top and they said it was closed, and seated us on the lower level, then a half hour later we saw service occurring upstairs - why pay for a supreme view of as a guest you can‚Äôt access it during ‚Äúopen‚Äù hours? We settled for the Lower level, still nice views and then at 10:55 we asked for one more drink - people had bottles of wine on ice still so we figured good to go. We were told by the waiter ‚Äú no the bar is closed‚Äù he then walked upstairs to the roof top area weren‚Äôt allowed to drink at. We continued to wait for our bill only to see the bartender make another full tray of drinks and coffee. What??!?! We were stung a bit but shrugged it off. Just felt wrong.
